chapter.title: Description of pre-built images
chapter.para: &slema; can be deployed using pre-built images. Currently, there are two types of images available: raw disk images and selfinstall ISOs.

&slema; raw images are delivered for the &x86-64; architecture, &zseries; ZSeries and also &aarch64;. The selfinstall images are currently delivered only for the &x86-64; architecture. The pre-built images are intended to be configured on the first boot by using either Ignition or Combustion. The boot loader detects the first boot; for more information see . Each image has default mounted subvolumes as described in . The procedure of deploying these images is described in .

important.title: Do not use firewall along with Podman
important.para: Using firewall along with Podman may result in missing Podman-related firewall rules after reloading the firewalld service. Therefore, it is recommended to keep the firewall disabled if you intend to use Podman.

note.title: &slema; as a &vmhost;
note.para: &slema; can run as a &kvm; host server—&xen; is not supported. However, there are several limitations of &slema; running as a &vmhost;; for details refer to virtualization limits and support.

sect1.title: Default partitioning
sect1.para: The pre-built images are delivered with a default partitioning scheme, which can be changed during the first boot by using Ignition or Combustion. For a procedure to repartition the system, refer to or .

important.title: Btrfs is mandatory for the root file system
important.para: If you intend to perform any changes to the default partitioning scheme, the root file system must be btrfs.

The images also have mounted subvolumes for booting by default. The specific subvolumes differ according to the architecture.
The /etc directory is mounted as OverlayFS, where the upper directory is mounted to /var/lib/overlay/1/etc/. For details, refer to .
You can recognize the subvolumes mounted by default by the option x-initrd.mount in /etc/fstab. Other subvolumes or partitions must be configured either by Ignition or Combustion.

sect1.title: First boot detection
sect1.para: The configuration runs on the first boot only. To distinguish between the first and subsequent boots, the flag file /boot/writable/firstboot_happened is created after the first boot took place. If the file is not present in the file system, the attribute ignition.firstboot is passed to the kernel command line, which triggers the creation of initramfs in case of Ignition or running the dracut module in case of Combustion. After completing the first boot, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.

note.title: The flag file is always created
note.para: Even though the configuration may not be successful, due to improper or missing configuration files, the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file is created.
You may force the first boot configuration on subsequent boot by passing the ignition.firstboot attribute to the kernel command line or by deleting the /boot/writable/firstboot_happened flag file.
